awd_titl_txt: FRG: Collaborative Research: Algebra and Geometry Behind Link Homology
awd_abstract_narration:
The Hecke algebra and its generalizations are central objects in modern representation theory. They naturally appear in number theory, representation theory, algebraic geometry, and even low-dimensional topology. A categorification of the Hecke algebra was used to define a new topological invariant of knots and links, known as HOMFLY-PT homology. However, it is extremely difficult to compute this invariant from the definition. The project is focused on understanding the algebraic, geometric, and combinatorial structure of link homology and categorified Hecke algebras, with the goal of unifying, deepening, and clarifying connections between these concepts.

Recent progress strongly indicates a connection between the HOMFLY-PT homology and algebraic geometry of the Hilbert scheme of points on the plane, a central object in modern algebraic geometry and geometric representation theory.  In this collaborative project, the investigators plan to compare and unify different approaches to the study of this connection and to develop the fundamental understanding of the relation between the category of Soergel bimodules and the Hilbert scheme. They also plan to provide an algebro-geometric construction of HOMFLY-PT homology and to understand its relation to the combinatorics of Macdonald polynomials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Since the project started in 2018, PI Gorskiy and co-PI Schilling published 40 papers and submitted another 11 preprints to journals. The research highlights include:

  • A series of papers with Hogancamp, Negut and Rasmussen outlining a precise conjectural relation between link homology and the Hilbert schemes of points on the plane, and a proof of these conjectures in important special cases.
  • A series of papers with Hogancamp, Negut and Wedrich on invariants of links in solid torus known as “categorical traces”
  • A series of papers with Chandler, Hogancamp, Mellit and Nakagane describing the structural properties of triply graded link homology such as (q,t) symmetry and Serre duality. In particular, this resolved the long-standing conjectures of Dunfield, Gukov and Rasmussen.
  • A series of papers with Kivinen, Mazin, Oblomkov, Simental and Vazirani on geometry and combinatorics of affine Springer fibers and their generalizations.
  • A series of papers with Casals, M. Gorsky, Le, Shen and Simental on braid varieties and their connections to algebraic geometry, symplectic geometry, combinatorics of Coxeter groups and cluster algebras. The explicit construction of cluster coordinates on braid varieties resolved a long-standing conjecture of Leclerc.
  • A series of papers with Colmenarejo, Orellana, Saliola and Zabrocki on diagram algebras, their representations, insertion algorithms and relations to plethysm coefficients.
  • Papers with various collaborators on crystal bases for super Lie algebras and combinatorial objects related to K-theory.
  • Various papers with Rhodes on new approaches to Markov chains using semigroup theory.
  • PI Gorskiy gave numerous talks on his research including a series of lectures on link homology at IHES summer school in 2021. The expanded lecture notes (written jointly with Kivinen and Simental) were published in the Bulletin of the London Mathematical Society.
  • co-PI Schilling gave numerous talks on her research including summer school lectures on crystal bases and lecture serious about combinatorics, integrable systems and quantum groups.

During the project, PI Gorskiy and co-PI Schilling mentored 15 graduate students and 4 postdocs in total. Two of Gorskiy’s students graduated  and started their tenure-track Assistant Professor positions (at Ohio State University and Aalto University in Finland), another student graduated and is currently a postdoc at Perimeter Institute. One of the postdocs started a tenure-track position at UNAM in Mexico City. Four of Schilling’s students graduated during the period of this project with postdoctoral positions at North Carolina State University and Colorado State University. Her postdoc started a tenure track position at Colorado State University.

The PIs and other co-PIs on this collaborative Focused Research Group project organized several workshops at UC Davis, University of Massachusetts and University of Oregon. Various subsets of the PIs have also organized workshops at ICERM and AIM closely related to the subjects of this project. co-PI Schilling organized FPSAC 2023 in Davis with almost 300 participants. The proceedings of this conference are published in Seminaire Lotharingien and the recorded lectures are available on Youtube.

During the COVID-19 pandemic, PI Gorskiy co-organized an online research community in link homology:

https://aimath.org/programs/researchcommunities/linkhom/

This was very successful and attracted over 150 researchers from all over the world at various stages of their careers, from graduate students to leading experts in the field. Over 80 talks were recorded and are publicly available online.
